awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: QIA: Large Scale QAOA Quantum Simulator
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a specialized Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) quantum circuit simulator. QAOA is the most studied quantum optimization algorithm and is considered to be the prime candidate for demonstrating quantum advantage. There is a worldwide race underway amongst top quantum information science researchers to find combinatorial optimization problems and their instances that run efficiently and faster on quantum devices rather than on classical computers. One of the critical bottlenecks is to find circuit parameters faster on a classical computer to accelerate variational quantum-classical frameworks. The expected improvements to the developed simulator will dramatically increase the speed of QAOA simulations by at least one order of magnitude and significantly speed up research done on finding optimal QAOA circuit parameters. As a result, it will help the realization of quantum advantage by US scientists in this highly competitive field of science.

The technical goal of this project is to carry out computational and algorithmic investigations in various node elimination methods for tensor contraction in the development of a scalable quantum simulator. The plan is to build upon the success of the combinatorial scientific computing community in developing elimination algorithms for such tasks as minimizing the error and complexity in matrix computations and optimizing the time and space complexity in automatic differentiation,  and recent developments in treewidth optimization algorithms. Additionally, in this project, emphasis will be placed on scaling up relevant graph algorithms to achieve acceptable time/quality trade-off for large-scale quantum simulators. Algorithmic and software products of this project will include a specialized QAOA quantum circuit open-source simulator equipped with fast optimization algorithms to accelerate tensor contraction methods. A high-quality simulator that scales to sufficiently large circuits is one of the major bottlenecks in discovering applications for demonstrating quantum advantage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at addressing the computational challenges in tensor network-based quantum circuit simulations, a cornerstone in the development of quantum computing technologies. Our focus was on design of efficient algorithms and methodologies to improve the simulation of quantum circuits, with an emphasis on Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) circuits. The outcomes of our research have significant implications for quantum computing, particularly in the simulation of quantum circuits on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. The project was structured around three main activities:


Activity 1: Optimal Contraction Tree Construction for Quantum Circuit Simulation


Outcome: We introduced a novel solver that transforms the problem into one of graph linear ordering. Our approach utilizes existing methodologies to achieve performance improvements by several orders of magnitude over current state-of-the-art methods. A polynomial-time algorithm was developed for constructing optimal contraction trees, significantly enhancing the efficiency of quantum circuit simulations. Our method demonstrated superior results in a series of tests involving QAOA circuits, outperforming competing methods in the majority of cases.

Activity 2: Parametrization of QAOA Circuits Using Graph Representation Learning

Outcome: Our research led to the development of a methodology for predicting optimal donor candidates with preoptimized parameters for target acceptor instances. This innovative approach allows for the acceleration of QAOA solvers, making the simulation of these circuits on NISQ devices more feasible. The use of preoptimized parameters from similar, smaller graphs substantially reduces the need for parameter optimization in larger graphs.

Activity 3: Optimization of General MPS for Tensor-Based Contraction

Outcome: This activity is focused on the optimization of general MPS to improve tensor-based contraction methods. The goal is to develop optimized algorithms that can contribute to the scalability and efficiency of QAOA simulations. This work was beyond what was planned and this work on this activity is ongoing, with a paper currently in progress. The completion and publication of the research paper will provide insights and methodologies for further enhancing the simulation of quantum circuits, particularly in the context of QAOA.

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2024
Modified by: Ilya Safro
